awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Ecological Genomics of Stress Response in an Intertidal Copepod
awd_abstract_narration:
A major goal of marine biological research is to understand the distribution and abundance of organisms in light of their adaptations to the environment. Such an understanding is critical to predicting how environmental changes will alter oceanic productivity and ecosystem services. Tolerance of physical extremes plays a major role in determining species distributions. Although the physiological tolerances of many marine animals have been well studied, the extent to which these tolerances can be adjusted by evolutionary change remains essentially unknown. Consequently, we often have knowledge of how individual organisms respond to environmental stresses but little understanding of whether existing genetic variation within species will permit rapid evolutionary responses to stressors such as global warming or ocean acidification.

Copepods are small crustaceans that are among the most numerous animals on the planet and are key components of marine and freshwater food webs.  Despite their ecological importance, only limited genetic data are available for any copepod species. In order to understand how these organisms can adapt to changes in their environment over both long and short time periods, this project will focus on obtaining genome sequences for the tidepool copepod, Tigriopus californicus, and then will use this genomic information to understand how the species responds to environmental change. The study has three major scientific components. First, the genome will be sequenced from four geographically isolated populations to allow comparison of genome-wide population differences. Target populations will be selected to provide contrasts in population responses to two key environmental stresses, thermal stress and salinity stress. The second component will be to examine which genes respond to these environmental stresses to help determine the mechanisms used to survive these two stresses.  Finally, the third component will use laboratory crosses and genetic mapping approaches to look at what regions of the genome confer tolerance to salinity and temperature stress. By integrating across all three aspects, this study will yield insights into how this species (and likely other organisms) respond to basic environmental stresses.

At a broader level, the decoding of a complete copepod genome will provide a key resource for understanding the basic biology of other species of this ecologically important group, with sequence data made available through standard databases and a newly-developed website (http://sio.ucsd.edu/Research/copepod_genomics/).  This project includes extensive outreach and will bring a public window into how modern marine science is conducted through programs for elementary school children and exhibits for visitors to public aquaria. Outreach will also be extended to the broader marine sciences community to help show how genomics can be used to study fundamental questions in marine systems that traditionally have not utilized genetic techniques. Finally, the research will directly train a number of young scientists in this exciting combination of marine science, physiology, and genomics.

por.por_cntn:
A fundamental goal of Biology is to understand factors controlling the abundance and distribution of organisms. For marine organisms, such an understanding is critical to predicting changes in oceanic productivity and ecosystem services. This project used a marine copepod, Tigriopus californicus, to assess how genetic variation within a species impacts physiological tolerance and the potential for evolutionary adaptation to environmental change. Copepods are small crustaceans that play important role in food webs and are among the most abundant organisms on the planet.

This project, which involved collaboration among four different labs, had three major research components. One component involved sequencing the complete genomes of eight T. californicus populations spanning a broad range of environmental stress tolerance.  Results showed thousands of genes that appear unique to the species, with an apparent proliferation of genes involved in moving substances across cell membranes and receiving chemical signals. Results also showed extraordinary population divergence for the mitochondrial genome (inherited from mothers), with elevated evolution in nuclear genes (inherited from both parents) that interact with the mitochondrial genes. The genomic data, which is the most complete to date for a copepod, is being made publicly available and will be an important resource for addressing basic questions about this group of organisms.

A second component of the project was to assess population differences in stress tolerance (including thermal, osmotic and pollution resistance), and to use laboratory crosses and genetic mapping approaches to determine regions of the genome contributing to tolerance. Work documented population differences in plastic physiological responses as well as evolved genetic differences in tolerance. Responses were typically sex-specific, and simultaneous exposure to different stressors often produced a synergistic response greater than the summed effects of individual stressors. Mapping studies detected gene regions underlying thermal tolerance on chromosomes 1 and 4.

A third component of the project was to identify specific genes responding to particular types of environmental stressors and determine how these genes differ among populations. Results documented population differentiation in genes responding to thermal, osmotic and pollution stress. Gene expression was found to be sex-specific and differed between short-term and long-term exposures. In some cases, simultaneous exposure to two stressors caused changes in gene expression not detected after exposure to either individual stressor.

Beyond the specific scientific objectives, this project had a number of broader impacts. The project trained a cadre of postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students, including opportunities for cross-training among the four collaborating institutions. The work also involved extensive outreach outside of academia, including hands-on molecular biology workshops for 5th grade students in San Diego, public events focused on marine evolution at an aquarium in Long Beach, and a new project developing evolution-themed curricula for K-12 students in downtown Los Angeles.
